PHL101.name: Introduction to Philosophy
PHL101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL101.description: Theories of knowledge, values, and reality. Topics such as objectivity, relativism and cultural diversity, moral responsibility, aesthetic values, the self, existence of God, free will, minds and machines.

PHL130.name: Logic and Reasoning
PHL130.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL130.description: Deductive and inductive reasoning. Topics such as rational argumentation, fallacies, definition, meaning, truth and evidence. Techniques for critical reading and thinking.

PHL210.name: Ancient Greek Philosophy
PHL210.description: Philosophical problems of existence, knowledge, and action as addressed in selected readings from the Presocratics, Plato, Aristotle, and Hellenistic philosophers.

PHL211.name: Modern Philosophy
PHL211.description: Philosophy from the Renaissance through the nineteenth century, including selections from Descartes, Spinoza, Locke, Leibniz, Berkeley, Hume, Kant, Nietzsche, and other prominent figures.

PHL212.name: Latin American Philosophy
PHL212.semester: Fall of odd years, Spring of even years
PHL212.description: A survey of historic and contemporary philosophical traditions from Latin America.

PHL213.name: Africana Philosophy
PHL213.semester: Fall of odd years, Spring of even years
PHL213.description: A survey of historic and contemporary philosophical traditions from Africa and African diasporas.

PHL214.name: Indigenous Philosophy
PHL214.semester: Fall of even years, Spring of odd years
PHL214.description: A survey of historic and contemporary philosophical traditions from Indigenous peoples globally.

PHL220.name: Existentialism
PHL220.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL220.description: Husserl, Jaspers, Kierkegaard, Marcel, Nietzsche, Sartre, and de Beauvoir. Topics such as hope, anxiety, bad faith, subjectivity, freedom, social being, phenomenological method.

PHL247.name: Aesthetics
PHL247.description: Aesthetic theories, philosophies of art, the role of art and aesthetics in culture and society. Discussion of major positions within the history of aesthetics, and contemporary problems and figures such as Plato, Kant, Hegel, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Gadamer, Adorno, Langer, and Danto.

PHL260.name: Philosophy of Religion
PHL260.description: Key concepts, themes, and questions in the philosophy of religion.

PHL291.name: Special Topics in Introductory Philosophy
PHL291.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL291.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings.

PHL315.name: African Philosophy
PHL315.description: Debates about the nature of philosophy in Africa and specific controversies about knowledge, rationality, metaphysics, morality, and politics. African philosophy in a global context.

PHL330.name: Formal Reasoning
PHL330.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL330.description: Formal methods in deductive reasoning. Logic of connectives and quantifiers including identity, functions, and descriptions.

PHL340.name: Ethics
PHL340.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL340.description: Inquiry through the writings of some important theorists, their critics and their contemporary followers. Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, Sidgwick.

PHL342.name: Environmental Ethics
PHL342.description: Ethical perspectives on humanity's use of and relationship to nonhuman animals, the land, future humans, and the ecosystem itself.

PHL344.name: Ethical Issues in Health Care
PHL344.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL344.description: Termination of treatment, truth-telling, informed consent, human experimentation, reproductive issues, allocation of scarce resources, justice and the health care system.
PHL344.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

PHL345.name: Business Ethics
PHL345.description: Ethical dimensions of the relationships between a business and employees, consumers, other businesses, society, government, and the law.
PHL345.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

PHL350.name: Introduction to Social and Political Philosophy
PHL350.description: History of social and political philosophy; problems such as obligation, power, oppression, freedom, equality, and community.

PHL353.name: Core Themes in Peace and Justice Studies
PHL353.description: Core themes in peace and justice studies, including concepts of violence, conflict and reconciliation as informed by problems of inequality, power, and recognition. Institutional and practical approaches to nonviolence.

PHL354.name: Philosophy of Law
PHL354.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL354.description: Legal concepts such as punishment, responsibility, rights and duties, and judicial decisions. Legal theories such as natural law, positivism and realism.

PHL355.name: Philosophy of Technology (W)
PHL355.description: Examination of the desirability of technology, its social forms, and its alternatives. Conventional productivist, ecological progressive, and radical humanist outlooks.
PHL355.prerequisite: (LB 133) or completion of Tier I writing requirement
PHL355.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Philosophy or in the Lyman Briggs College or in the Science, Technology, Environment and Public Policy Specialization.

PHL356.name: Philosophical Aspects of Feminism
PHL356.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL356.description: Conceptual and normative issues in feminist theory. Topics such as sexism, oppression, coercion, control, power, equality, personhood, respect and self-respect, rape, separatism, community, intimacy, and autonomy.

PHL357.name: Philosophy of Karl Marx
PHL357.description: Marx's philosophical thought and its bearing on science, religion, art and politics.

PHL358.name: Philosophy, Gender, and Global Development
PHL358.description: Gender and development in a global context from a feminist and philosophical perspective. Gender, oppression and embodiment. Diversity, the politics of difference, and women’s identity. Multiculturalism, postcolonialism and transculturalism. Feminism, international development, and global justice.

PHL361.name: Knowledge and Reality
PHL361.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL361.description: Introduction to the main problems in epistemology and metaphysics. Topics vary and may include

PHL380.name: Nature of Science
PHL380.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL380.description: Conflicting views about science and values. Such topics as scientific methodology; the objectivity and value neutrality of science; the presuppositions, goals, and limits of science; and science and decision making.

PHL391.name: Special Topics in Intermediate Philosophy
PHL391.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL391.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings.

PHL410.name: Socrates and Plato Seminar
PHL410.description: A selection of themes (ontology, epistemology, method, ethics) from Plato’s Socratic and constructive dialogues. Variable by term in content.

PHL411.name: Aristotle Seminar
PHL411.description: Aristotle's major works and his major contributions to the metaphysics, psychology, ethics, the arts, and politics. Variable by term in content.

PHL413.name: Seminar in Early Modern Philosophy
PHL413.description: Topics selected from among the works of 17th and 18th century philosophers, e.g., Descartes, Spinoza, Locke, Leibniz, Berkeley, and Hume. Variable by term in content.

PHL415.name: Kant Seminar
PHL415.description: A seminar in Immanuel Kant’s critical philosophy in metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, political philosophy, aesthetics, or other areas. Variable by term in content.

PHL416.name: Hegel Seminar
PHL416.description: Hegel's dialectic and its bearing on both the history of philosophy and issues about science, politics, art and religion.

PHL417.name: Seminar in 19th Century Philosophy
PHL417.description: Selections from Post-Hegelian German philosophy, Mill and Utilitarianism, early African-American philosophy, Nietzsche and proto-existentialism, or American Pragmatism. Variable by term in content.

PHL418.name: Seminar in 20th Century Philosophy
PHL418.description: Emphasis on important philosophers or movements in the analytic or continental traditions of the 20th century, extending to the present. Variable by term in content and approach.

PHL419.name: Topics in the History of Philosophy
PHL419.description: Emphasis on one of the less frequently taught themes, philosophers, and movements in the history of philosophy.

PHL421.name: Topics in European and Continental Philosophy
PHL421.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL421.description: Discussion of movements, issues, or figures in Continental and European Philosophy. Variable by term in content.

PHL431.name: Topics in Philosophy of Logic and Language
PHL431.description: Investigation of logical concepts. Philosophical significance of twentieth-century results in logic. Related issues in the semantics and pragmatics of natural language.

PHL432.name: Logic and its Metatheory
PHL432.description: Logical consequence, first-order predicate logic with identity, including functions and descriptions. Proof theory and model theory. Topics in metatheory such as completeness, compactness, and the Lowenheim-Skolem Theorems. The axiomatic method and Godel's Incompleteness Theorems.

PHL440.name: Central Issues in Ethics
PHL440.description: Twentieth-century discussions of universalization, utilitarianism, nature of a moral theory, moral language, relativism, skepticism, theory and practice, weakness of will, moral education, and justification.

PHL442.name: Ethics and Animals
PHL442.description: Moral standing for non-human animals, basis for human moral obligations to animals, animal's cognitive abilities. Ethics of using animals in specific ways
PHL442.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

PHL444.name: Philosophical Issues in Biomedicine
PHL444.description: Philosophically puzzling features of medical research, policy, and practice. Issues in theories of knowledge, personal identity, reference and meaning.

PHL451.name: Philosophy and the Black Experience
PHL451.description: Philosophical issues about race and the black experience. Nature of racism, relationship of science to race, debates about identity, public policy and race.

PHL452.name: Ethics and Development
PHL452.description: Ethical issues such as racism, health care disparities, war, genocide, famine, agricultural intensification, economic liberalization, democratization, gender equity, globalization, and environmental degradation.

PHL453.name: Ethical Issues in Global Public Health
PHL453.description: Ethical issues about public health from a global perspective. Health and illness in the context of development, poverty, technological change, resource conflicts, the distribution of power, and social violence. Values and policy issues regarding resources, environment, and the distribution and quality of health care.

PHL454.name: Topics in Philosophy of Law
PHL454.description: Selected topics in philosophical approaches to law such as critical race theory, constitutional theory and international law.
PHL454.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
PHL454.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Philosophy or approval of department.

PHL456.name: Topics in Feminist Philosophy
PHL456.description: Philosophical issues in a framework of feminist politics and critique. Standpoint theories, care/justice ethics, ontological status of genders/races, theories of power/domination, determinism/freedom.

PHL460.name: Epistemology
PHL460.description: Theories and concepts of knowledge, belief, epistemic justification, certainty, and reason.

PHL461.name: Metaphysics
PHL461.description: Basic concepts employed in trying to understand the nature of things. Concepts include universals, particulars, things, kinds, properties, events, persons, change, causality, chance, existence, possibility, necessity, space, and time.

PHL462.name: Philosophy of Mind
PHL462.description: Modern theories of the mind, other minds, and the mind's relation to the body. Theories include dualism, behaviorism, criteriology, reductive and eliminative materialism, and functionalism.

PHL463.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
PHL463.description: Cognitive processing of information by animals, humans, and computers. Relevant issues in philosophy, linguistics, psychology, neurophysiology, and artificial intelligence.

PHL480.name: Philosophy of Science
PHL480.description: Structure of scientific theories and explanation. Causation, prediction, induction, confirmation, discovery, and scientific progress.

PHL486.name: Biotechnology in Agriculture: Applications and Ethical Issues
PHL486.description: Current and future roles of biotechnology in agriculture
PHL486.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

PHL490.name: Independent Study
PHL490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL490.description: Supervised special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

PHL491.name: Special Topics in Philosophy
PHL491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL491.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings, proposed by faculty on a group study basis.

PHL492.name: Capstone for Majors (W)
PHL492.description: Advanced, variable topic seminar for undergraduate majors. Presentations, substantial written work.
PHL492.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
PHL492.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of Philosophy or approval of department.

PHL493.name: Philosophy Internship
PHL493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL493.description: Supervised pre-professional field experience in such philosophy-related careers as found in legal, healthcare, legislative or non-profit settings.
PHL493.prerequisite: (Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement) and (PHL 130 or PHL 330) and (PHL 210 or PHL 211)
PHL493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department.

PHL499.name: Senior Thesis (W)
PHL499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL499.description: Individual research project supervised by a faculty member that demonstrates the student's ability to do independent research and submit or present a major paper.
PHL499.prerequisite: (PHL 130 or PHL 330 or PHL 432) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PHL499.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of Philosophy. Approval of department.

PHL800.name: Proseminar in Philosophy
PHL800.description: The practice of graduate and professional work in philosophy
PHL800.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Department of Philosophy or approval of department.

PHL801.name: Teaching Philosophy
PHL801.description: Theoretical and pedagogical issues in teaching philosophy
PHL801.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the Department of Philosophy or approval of department.

PHL810.name: Seminar in the History of Philosophy
PHL810.description: Major thinkers, themes, periods, or movements in the history of philosophy.
PHL810.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL820.name: Seminar in Continental Philosophy
PHL820.description: Major figures or themes in 19th and 20th century continental philosophy.
PHL820.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL830.name: Graduate Seminar in Logic and Language
PHL830.description: Graduate-level investigation of logical concepts, the philosophical significance of results in logic and the philosophy of language over the past 150 years, and related issues in the semantics and pragmatics of natural language.

PHL840.name: Seminar in Value Theory
PHL840.description: Major figures, themes, or periods in ethics or aesthetics. Topics vary.
PHL840.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL850.name: Seminar in Social and Political Philosophy
PHL850.description: Major figures, themes, or periods in social and political philosophy. Topics vary.
PHL850.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL860.name: Seminar in Metaphysics and Epistemology
PHL860.description: Selected topics in metaphysics, epistemology, and philosophy of mind.
PHL860.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL867.name: Nature and Practice of Cognitive Science
PHL867.description: Survey of how different disciplines explore the cognitive processes underlying intelligent behavior.

PHL870.name: Seminar in Philosophy of Health Care
PHL870.description: Ethical, political, theoretical, and methodological issues in medicine and health care.
PHL870.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL880.name: Seminar in Philosophy of Science
PHL880.description: Selected topics in the philosophy of the special sciences, in the metatheory of science, and in the social studies of science.
PHL880.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL890.name: Independent Study
PHL890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL890.description: Special projects, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

PHL894.name: Practicum in Philosophy of Health Care
PHL894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHL894.description: Study of ethical and policy issues in hospital and governmental agency settings.
PHL894.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Philosophy major or approval of department.

PHL897.name: Seminar in Feminist Theories, Epistemologies, and Pedagogy
PHL897.description: Foundational knowledge, theory, epistemology, and pedagogy in women’s and gender studies from a multi-disciplinary, global perspective.

PHL899.name: Master's Thesis Research
PHL899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHL899.description: Directed research leading to a master's thesis in partial fulfillment of Plan A master's degree requirements.

PHL999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PHL999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
